[[Image:Rudy Guiliani at a NYFPC briefing.jpg|right|thumb|250px|Rudy Giuliani at a [[United States Department of State|State Department]] briefing with [[Bernard Kerik]] and others. September 2002.]] [[Rudy Giuliani]], as [[Mayoralty of Rudy Giuliani|mayor of the City of New York]], promoted the career of [[Bernard Kerik]] (by appointment or recommendation) on several occasions. Critics have charged that Giuliani showed consistently poor judgment in doing so.
==History of promotions== [[Bernard Kerik]], who started out as a [[New York Police Department]] detective driving for his campaign, then became the city's Commissioner of the [[New York City Department of Correction|Department of Correction]] and later [[New York City Police Commissioner]] and a founder of [[Giuliani Partners]]. Kerik also served as bodyguard for Giuliani.<ref>Fred Kaplan, [http://slate.com/id/2110638/ "Is Bernard Kerik Qualified to Run Homeland Security?"], slate.com, December 3, 2004</ref><ref>Associated Press, [http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/21491113/ "Giuliani's Police Chief Could be a Problem: Case of ex-NYC police commissioner could crash into final push for votes"], October 26, 2007</ref> Giuliani is godfather to Kerik's two younger children, by Kerik's third wife, Hala Matli (born 1972, married 1998): Celine Christina and Angelina Amber.<ref>CNN, [http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/0412/11/cst.01.html CNN Live Saturday transcript], December 11, 2004</ref>
More than half of mayor Giuliani's cabinet opposed his 2000 appointment of Kerik as police commissioner.<ref name=Loyalty>Michael Powell, [http://www.nytimes.com/2007/11/03/us/politics/03kerik.html?hp "Loyal to Kerik, Giuliani Missed Warning Signs"], "New York Times," November 3, 2007</ref> Kerik's selection came despite the fact that he lacked a college degree. (Kerik was a high school dropout with a [[General Equivalency Diploma]].<ref>Christopher Drew, [http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9A0DE0DD1631F930A35751C1A9629C8B63&sec=&spon=&pagewanted=all "A Street Cop's Rise From High School Dropout to Cabinet Nominee"], New York Times, November 3, 2004</ref>) Possession of a college degree was a requirement of police department officials at the captain rank and higher,<ref name=Loyalty /> a practice instituted by former police commissioner [[Benjamin Ward]].
After Giuliani's terms as mayor completed, Kerik became a founder of [[Giuliani Partners]].
Giuliani then pushed President [[George W. Bush]] to nominate Kerik to be [[Secretary of Homeland Security]], at which point multiple scandals derailed the nomination and Kerik's career; subsequently Kerik pled guilty to corruption charges dating from his Corrections days (1999). (He pled guilty in Bronx court to state misdemeanor charges related to undeclared acceptance of $165,000 in apartment renovations performed by Interstate Industrial, a reputably mob-associated firm.)<ref name=Loyalty /><ref name="allies">Tom Brune, [http://www.newsday.com/news/nationworld/nation/ny-usrudy225104307feb22,0,4518656.story "Allies could cause alarm"], ''[[Newsday]]'', February 22, 2007. Accessed March 3, 2007.</ref> In March 2007, ''The New York Times'' reported that Kerik was likely to also be indicted for tax fraud and illegal eavesdropping, and also disclosed that Giuliani had testified under oath in April 2006 that he had in fact been briefed on Kerik's mob links in 2000 â€” prior to his appointment of Kerik as Corrections Commissioner. Giuliani had previously denied knowing of these connections until years later.<ref>[http://www.nytimes.com/2007/04/01/us/politics/01rudy.html?_r=1&oref=slogin "Giuliani Says Ties to Kerik May Hurt Him With Voters"], New York Times, April 1, 2007</ref> Kerik is also under investigation for conspiracy to [[eavesdrop]] on the conversations of the husband of [[Jeanine Pirro]], [[Albert Pirro]], whom Ms. Pirro suspected of having an affair.<ref>[http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/03/31/AR2007033100769.html "Ex-NYC Commish Rejects Plea Deal"], The Washington Post, March 31, 2007</ref>
==Briefing of Giuliani== Mayor Giuliani said that neither he nor his aides could remember being briefed about Kerik's involvement with Interstate Industrial. However, a late 2007 ''[[New York Times]]'' investigation of the diaries and investigator's notes of Edward J. Kuriansky, the city investigations commissioner, indicates that such a meeting did indeed occur. Additionally, Kuriansky also remembered briefing one of Giuliani's closest aides, Dennison Young Jr., about Kerik's involvement with Interstate Industrial just days before the police commissioner appointment. Regarding Giuliani's appointment patterns and loyalty as a factor in professional relationships, former deputy mayor (under Giuliani) Fran Reiter said, "Rudy can fall for people big time, and sometimes qualifications are secondary to loyalty."<ref name=Loyalty />
==Effect on Giuliani presidential campaign== Marc Mukasey, son of [[Michael Mukasey]] (then [[Attorney General]]) and member of [[Bracewell & Giuliani]], has been assigned by [[Rudy Giuliani presidential campaign, 2008|Giuliani's 2008 presidential campaign]] to block Kerik's legal defense team from interviewing witnesses that might assist his defense.<ref>Larry Celona and Dan Manigan, [http://www.nypost.com/seven/10222007/news/regionalnews/giuliani_bern_shield.htm "Giuliani's Bernard Kerik Shield: Pal Keeps Eye on Ex-NYPD Boss' Probe"], ''[[New York Post]]'' Exclusive, October 22, 2007</ref> (When Giuliani joined the Bracewell firm, effecting the company's name change to [[Bracewell & Giuliani]], he brought Marc Mukasey into the firm.<ref>{{cite news | title=White House Says Mukasey Would Skip Giuliani Issues | author=William K. Rashbaum | publisher=[[The New York Times]] | date=2007-09-29}}</ref>)
During a November 5, 2007 presidential campaign visit in [[Derry, New Hampshire]], Giuliani said, "I think Bernie Kerik, I should have checked out more carefully. I've said that. I've apologized for it."<ref name="fn110507">[http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,308340,00.html "Rudy Giuliani Defends Bernard Kerik's Record Amid Bribery Investigation"], Fox News, November 5, 2007</ref> Giuliani then stressed Kerik's contribution to crime reduction in New York, as well as his record as Corrections Commissioner: "But the reality is we brought down crime in record proportions, we brought down violence in the prisons by record proportions."<ref name="fn110507" /> (However, Kerik had a relatively short term in New York City's police commissioner. He served for one year and four months, compared with the longer tenures of [[William Bratton]] and [[Howard Safir]].) On November 8, Giuliani declined to say whether he would grant Kerik a [[presidential pardon]] were the circumstances to come about: "It wouldn't be fair to ask that question at this point. He may or may not be charged, he may or may not be convicted. Who knows what happens?"<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/wn_report/2007/11/09/2007-11-09_rudy_giuliani_wont_say_if_hed_pardon_ker.html | title= Rudy Giuliani won't say if he'd pardon Kerik as President | publisher=[[New York Daily News]] | author=Mary Rae Bragg, David Saltonstall | date=2007-11-09 | accessdate=2007-11-09}}</ref>
Of Giuliani's Republican opponents, Senator [[John McCain]] was the most outspoken regarding the Kerik association and the doubt it cast upon Giuliani's judgement, saying, "That's why I never would've supported him to be the head of Homeland Security because of his irresponsible act when he was over in Baghdad to try and help train the police. One of the reasons why we had so much trouble with the initial training of the police was because he came, didn't do anything and then went out to the airport and left."<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.usatoday.com/news/politics/election2008/2007-11-09-mccain-kerik_N.htm | title=McCain hammers Kerik, questions Giuliani's judgment | publisher=[[Associated Press]]| author=Philip Elliott | date=2007-11-09 | accessdate=2007-11-10}}</ref>
On November 13, 2007, former publisher [[Judith Regan]], with whom Kerik had had an extramarital affair, filed a $100 million defamation lawsuit against [[News Corporation]], claiming among other things that News Corporation executives told her in 2004 to lie to federal investigators about her relationship with Kerik, in order to protect Giuliani's future presidential campaign.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.calendarlive.com/books/la-na-regan14nov14,0,4904579.story | title=Regan says she was told to lie to protect Giuliani | author=Josh Getlin | publisher=[[Los Angeles Times]] | date=2007-11-14 | accessdate=2007-11-14}}</ref>
By late December 2007, the Kerik relationship was seen as one of the factors leading a difficult stretch for the Giuliani campaign.<ref name="nyt122407">{{cite news | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2007/12/24/us/politics/24giuliani.html | title=Giuliani Hits a Rocky Stretch as Voting Approaches | author=[[Adam Nagourney]] | publisher=[[The New York Times]] | date=2007-12-24 | accessdate=2007-12-24}}</ref>
